Under One Sun The Treaty and Land Claim Edition

The Great Canadian Treaty & Land Claim Project

Our class made presentations on Indigenous treaties and land claims. This map shows some of the treaties and land claims we studied.

West Coast Treaties and Land Claims

Timeline by Jaxon Geary

The Canadian government didn’t start making treaties with West Coast First Nations until the 1800s, but it stopped around 1900, leaving most of British Columbia without treaties until recently. This timeline shows some of the historic and modern treaties.

West Coast Treaties and Land Claims

1850
1850–1854: James Douglas, a fur trader and governor of Vancouver Island, acquires First Nations land on the island. Douglas’s purchases, called the Douglas Treaties, are the first treaties in British Columbia.
1870
1871: British Columbia becomes a province. The new provincial government agrees that the federal government has the power to make laws for First Nations people and their land.
1890
1899: The government signs Treaty 8, which includes parts of British Columbia, Alberta, Saskatchewan, and the Northwest Territories. This treaty makes it easier for the government to access and sell land. The treaty still governs the region today.
1900
1900–1990: For almost 100 years, the government of British Columbia refuses to sign treaties, even though many First Nations want to negotiate agreements to protect their lands.
1950
1990
1990: A process begins to negotiate a modern treaty between the government and the Nisga’a Nation.
1992: The Treaty Commission and the treaty process are established between the governments of Canada, British Columbia, and First Nations.
2000
2000: The Nisga’a Final Agreement comes into effect in May 2000. It is the first treaty signed by a First Nation in British Columbia since Treaty 8 in 1899.
2008
2008: The Tsawwassen First Nation Treaty is signed on April 3. The Tsawwassen reserve expands, and the Nation receives $16 million, the right to govern itself, and a portion of the Fraser River salmon catch.
2010
2011: On April 1, the Maa-nulth First Nations Final Agreement becomes law. The five Vancouver Island bands involved receive more than 245 square kilometres and more than $75 million. The agreement also includes the possibility of self-government and asserts the peoples’ rights to minerals, timber, and wildlife.
2014
2014: Tsilhqot’in First Nation wins a Supreme Court decision on its land claim, and about 440 square kilometres are returned to the First Nation.

As of 2017, more than 60 First Nations are involved in negotiating 49 agreements with the British Columbia government. About 60 percent of First Nations in British Columbia have entered into the treaty process.

Prairie Treaties

Interviews by Chris Sanderson

My assignment was to interview people who live on the Prairies to learn what they know about treaties there. All three provinces are negotiating land claims, which First Nations file when they haven’t received land they were promised under treaty. My kokum, Wanda Abernathy, used to live in Alberta. I interviewed her first.

CHRIS: Okay, so I know Bigstone Cree Nation members received land under the treaty they signed in 1899. Why was there a land claim?
WANDA: The government didn’t count the members who were living north of Bigstone Cree, even though those people were entitled to land. The Nation didn’t receive all the land it was entitled to, so it filed a land claim, and in 2010, a settlement was reached. It was the biggest treaty land entitlement in Alberta.
CHRIS: Why is this settlement important?
WANDA: It gave the people of Bigstone Cree new schools, housing, and water treatment. Just as importantly, it let people know that unfulfilled treaty promises can be fulfilled. Even if it takes 100 years, like this one did!

Next, I interviewed Martin Ross, an Elder from the Kahkewistahaw First Nation, about Saskatchewan treaties.

CHRIS: I know your Nation lost reserve land in 1907. What happened?
MR. ROSS: After our people signed Treaty 4 in 1874, they received their reserve. But soon the local government wanted the best parts of the reserve, and land was just taken from our people.
CHRIS: I read that a land claim was settled in 2003, and that Kahkewistahaw First Nation received $94.6 million. How has the money been used?
MR. ROSS: The money’s been used for land, businesses, housing, and a new school.
CHRIS: In your opinion, what’s the future of land claims in Saskatchewan?
MR. ROSS: New claims are being settled every year. Experts think that 9718 square kilometres of land will eventually be returned to Saskatchewan First Nations. I think that as more Canadians become aware of the treaties, we’ll be able to move toward the relationship we should have had all along: nation to nation.

Finally, I talked to Betty Gill to find out about treaties in Manitoba, where she lives and volunteers with several First Nations to work on land claims.

CHRIS: Hi, Mrs. Gill. Can you tell me about the Manitoba Treaty Land Entitlement Framework Agreement?
MRS. GILL: The agreement is between the governments of Canada and Manitoba, and 21 First Nations. Under it, the Nations will receive up to 5747 square kilometres of land that they are owed, once their claims are settled.
CHRIS: I’ve heard that there are Métis land claims happening, as well?
MRS. GILL: Yes! In the Manitoba Act of 1870, the Canadian government promised that Métis lands would be protected, but they weren’t. The government also promised to set aside land for thousands of Métis children, but many never received anything. So in 2013, the Supreme Court ruled that the government hadn’t fulfilled its promises to the Métis.
CHRIS: What have the Métis done since then?
MRS. GILL: We’re making progress, but settling land claims can take years. It’s going to take time, but at least we are finally moving forward.

When I first learned about treaties in school, I thought they were purely historical. What I learned from my interviews is that treaties are still being negotiated. They are not ancient history but modern agreements that still affect us today.

Northern Land Claims

Speech by Jenna Haigh

Hello! As part of our class’s unit about First Nations treaties, I’ll be telling you about some land claims in Canada’s North and why you should care.

The first claim is the Inuvialuit Final Agreement. It was signed on July 25, 1984, and was the first land claim agreement ever settled in the Northwest Territories.

  • The Inuvialuit negotiated with the Canadian government for 10 years before reaching an agreement.
  • The Inuvialuit now own an area that covers about 90 600 square kilometres. Their ownership includes mineral rights, $152 million dollars, and the right to hunt on the land.

Next up is the Gwich’in Comprehensive Land Claim Agreement, which was signed in April 1992.

  • The Gwich’in are First Nations people who live in the Northwest Territories and Yukon.
  • The Gwich’in received 22 422 square kilometres in the Northwest Territories and 1554 square kilometres in Yukon.
  • They also received more than $75 million and will receive other payments each year. As well, the Gwich’in have begun negotiating for self-government.

The last agreement is the Nunavut Agreement of 1993.

  • It is Canada’s largest Indigenous land claim settlement. Inuit now own about one-fifth of Nunavut.
  • Under the agreement, Inuit have the right to manage the environment and wildlife in this area.
  • What’s most important about this agreement is that it made Inuit self-governing. Nunavut became Canada’s newest territory on April 1, 1999.

I didn’t know much about Canada’s North or its peoples before I began this project, but I’ve learned a lot about their deep connection to the land, as well as their rights. They never agreed to give up anything; their land and their rights were simply taken from them. To me, it’s only right that these things are returned to them.

Treaties in the Atlantic Provinces

Information Report by Devon Ackee

In Canada’s Atlantic provinces, Peace and Friendship Treaties were negotiated between the British Crown and First Nations starting in the 1700s. Because many of the historic treaties were unclear, new agreements are being negotiated.

New Brunswick

In November 2016, the Elsipogtog First Nation filed a land claim that covers about one-third of New Brunswick. Since 2013, they’ve been protesting a project to extract gas from shale beds that lie below some of this land. Many non–First Nations people also don’t want this development.

Nova Scotia

To settle disagreements over historic treaties, the Mi’kmaq, Nova Scotia government, and Canadian government signed a Framework Agreement in 2002. It created a process to begin settling land claims by various First Nations.

Prince Edward Island

In 2012, the federal and provincial governments signed an agreement to consult with the Mi’kmaq Confederacy of Prince Edward Island about land usage that might affect their people. The Mi’kmaq Confederacy on the island says that it never agreed to give up any land.

Newfoundland and Labrador

The Innu people of Labrador never signed treaties with the government, so in October 1990 they filed a land claim to protect their rights to their traditional land. The Innu Nation, provincial government, and federal government are still negotiating an agreement.

Let’s Talk

  1. What does the phrase “we are all treaty people” mean to you?
  2. Why is it important for Canada to negotiate modern treaties and settle land claims with Indigenous peoples?
